Class condition_variable

boost::sync::condition_variable — The condition variable class.

Synopsis

// In header: <boost/sync/condition_variables/condition_variable.hpp>


class condition_variable {
public:
  // types
  typedef unspecified native_handle_type;

  // construct/copy/destruct
  condition_variable();
  condition_variable(condition_variable const &) = delete;
  condition_variable & operator=(condition_variable const &) = delete;
  ~condition_variable();

  // public member functions
  void notify_one() noexcept;
  void notify_all() noexcept;
  template<typename Mutex> void wait(unique_lock< Mutex > &);
  template<typename Mutex, typename Predicate> 
    void wait(unique_lock< Mutex > &, Predicate);
  template<typename Mutex, typename Time> 
    bool timed_wait(unique_lock< Mutex > &, Time const &);
  template<typename Mutex, typename Time, typename Predicate> 
    bool timed_wait(unique_lock< Mutex > &, Time const &, Predicate);
  template<typename Mutex, typename Duration> 
    cv_status wait_for(unique_lock< Mutex > &, Duration const &);
  template<typename Mutex, typename Duration, typename Predicate> 
    bool wait_for(unique_lock< Mutex > &, Duration const &, Predicate);
  template<typename Mutex, typename TimePoint> 
    cv_status wait_until(unique_lock< Mutex > &, TimePoint const &);
  template<typename Mutex, typename TimePoint, typename Predicate> 
    bool wait_until(unique_lock< Mutex > &, TimePoint const &, Predicate);
  native_handle_type native_handle() noexcept;
};

Description

condition_variable public types

  1. typedef unspecified native_handle_type;

    Note

    This type is only available if BOOST_SYNC_DEFINES_CONDITION_VARIABLE_NATIVE_HANDLE macro is defined by the library.

condition_variable public construct/copy/destruct

  1. condition_variable();
    Default constructor.

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to create the primitive (e.g. due to insufficient resources). 

  2. condition_variable(condition_variable const &) = delete;
  3. condition_variable & operator=(condition_variable const &) = delete;
  4. ~condition_variable();
    Destructor.

    Destroys the condition variable.

    Requires:

    There are no threads blocked on the object.

condition_variable public member functions

  1. void notify_one() noexcept;
    Wakes up one thread blocked on the object. 
  2. void notify_all() noexcept;
    Wakes up all threads blocked on the object. 
  3. template<typename Mutex> void wait(unique_lock< Mutex > & lock);
    Blocks the current thread on the object.

    Atomically unlocks the mutex and blocks on the object. When unblocked, it locks the mutex and returns. The function can unblock upon another thread calling notify_one(), notify_all() or spuriously.

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to fulfill the request. The mutex is left in the locked state in case of exception.

    Parameters:

    lock

    Lock object

    Requires:

    Mutex is on of the mutex types compatible with condition_variable.

    Requires:

    lock.owns_lock() == true and lock.mutex() is locked by the current thread.

    Requires:

    There are no other threads blocked on the object or the blocked threads used the same mutex returned by lock.mutex() to block on this object.

    		 
  4. template<typename Mutex, typename Predicate> 
  void wait(unique_lock< Mutex > & lock, Predicate pred);
    Blocks the current thread on the object until the predicate is satisfied.

    Works equivalent to:

    while (!pred()) wait(lock);

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to fulfill the request. The mutex is left in the locked state in case of exception.

    Parameters:

    lock

    Lock object

    pred

    Condition predicate

    Requires:

    Mutex is on of the mutex types compatible with condition_variable.

    Requires:

    lock.owns_lock() == true and lock.mutex() is locked by the current thread.

    Requires:

    There are no other threads blocked on the object or the blocked threads used the same mutex returned by lock.mutex() to block on this object.

    		 
  5. template<typename Mutex, typename Time> 
  bool timed_wait(unique_lock< Mutex > & lock, Time const & timeout);
    Blocks the current thread on the object until the timeout expires.

    Atomically unlocks the mutex and blocks on the object. When unblocked, it locks the mutex and returns. The function can unblock after the specified timeout expires, upon another thread calling notify_one(), notify_all() or spuriously, whichever happens first. The timeout can be specified as an absolute time point or duration.

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to fulfill the request. The mutex is left in the locked state in case of exception.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    lock

    Lock object

    timeout

    Relative or absolute timeout. If timeout is relative, the time is measured according to the system clock.

    Requires:

    Mutex is on of the mutex types compatible with condition_variable.

    Requires:

    lock.owns_lock() == true and lock.mutex() is locked by the current thread.

    Requires:

    There are no other threads blocked on the object or the blocked threads used the same mutex returned by lock.mutex() to block on this object.

    Returns:

    true if the function returned before the timeout expired, otherwise false.

    		 
  6. template<typename Mutex, typename Time, typename Predicate> 
  bool timed_wait(unique_lock< Mutex > & lock, Time const & timeout, 
                  Predicate pred);
    Blocks the current thread on the object until the predicate is satisfied or the timeout expires.

    If the timeout is an absolute time point, works equivalent to:

    while (!pred()) if (!timed_wait(lock, timeout)) return pred();

    otherwise works as if equivalent to:

    auto abs_timeout = chrono::system_clock::now() + timeout; while (!pred()) if (!timed_wait(lock, abs_timeout)) return pred();

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to fulfill the request. The mutex is left in the locked state in case of exception.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    lock

    Lock object

    pred

    Condition predicate

    timeout

    Relative or absolute timeout. If timeout is relative, the time is measured according to the system clock.

    Requires:

    Mutex is on of the mutex types compatible with condition_variable.

    Requires:

    lock.owns_lock() == true and lock.mutex() is locked by the current thread.

    Requires:

    There are no other threads blocked on the object or the blocked threads used the same mutex returned by lock.mutex() to block on this object.

    		 
  7. template<typename Mutex, typename Duration> 
  cv_status wait_for(unique_lock< Mutex > & lock, 
                     Duration const & rel_timeout);
    Blocks the current thread on the object until the timeout expires.

    Atomically unlocks the mutex and blocks on the object. When unblocked, it locks the mutex and returns. The function can unblock after the specified timeout expires, upon another thread calling notify_one(), notify_all() or spuriously, whichever happens first. The timeout must be specified as a time duration.

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to fulfill the request. The mutex is left in the locked state in case of exception.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    lock

    Lock object

    Requires:

    Mutex is on of the mutex types compatible with condition_variable.

    Requires:

    lock.owns_lock() == true and lock.mutex() is locked by the current thread.

    Requires:

    There are no other threads blocked on the object or the blocked threads used the same mutex returned by lock.mutex() to block on this object.

    Returns:

    cv_status::no_timeout if the function returned before the timeout expired, otherwise cv_status::timeout.

    		 
  8. template<typename Mutex, typename Duration, typename Predicate> 
  bool wait_for(unique_lock< Mutex > & lock, Duration const & rel_timeout, 
                Predicate pred);
    Blocks the current thread on the object until the timeout expires.

    Works equivalent to:

    return wait_until(lock, chrono::system_clock::now() + rel_timeout, pred);

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to fulfill the request. The mutex is left in the locked state in case of exception.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    lock

    Lock object

    pred

    Condition predicate

    Requires:

    Mutex is on of the mutex types compatible with condition_variable.

    Requires:

    lock.owns_lock() == true and lock.mutex() is locked by the current thread.

    Requires:

    There are no other threads blocked on the object or the blocked threads used the same mutex returned by lock.mutex() to block on this object.

    		 
  9. template<typename Mutex, typename TimePoint> 
  cv_status wait_until(unique_lock< Mutex > & lock, 
                       TimePoint const & abs_timeout);
    Blocks the current thread on the object until the timeout expires.

The function can unblock after the specified timeout expires, upon another thread calling notify_one(), notify_all() or spuriously, whichever happens first. The timeout must be specified as an absolute time point.

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to fulfill the request. The mutex is left in the locked state in case of exception.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    Lock object

    Requires:

    Requires:

    Returns:

    cv_status::no_timeout if the function returned before the timeout expired, otherwise cv_status::timeout.

    		 
  10. template<typename Mutex, typename TimePoint, typename Predicate> 
  bool wait_until(unique_lock< Mutex > & lock, TimePoint const & abs_timeout, 
                  Predicate pred);
    Blocks the current thread on the object until the timeout expires.

    Works equivalent to:

    while (!pred()) if (wait_until(lock, timeout) == cv_status::timeout) return pred();

    Throws: An exception in case if the operating system is unable to fulfill the request. The mutex is left in the locked state in case of exception.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    lock

    Lock object

    pred

    Condition predicate

    Requires:

    Mutex is on of the mutex types compatible with condition_variable.

    Requires:

    lock.owns_lock() == true and lock.mutex() is locked by the current thread.

    Requires:

    There are no other threads blocked on the object or the blocked threads used the same mutex returned by lock.mutex() to block on this object.

    		 
  11. native_handle_type native_handle() noexcept;
    Returns a handle that represents a native operating system primitive that implements the condition variable.
    Note

    This method is only available if BOOST_SYNC_DEFINES_CONDITION_VARIABLE_NATIVE_HANDLE macro is defined by the library.
